body:
Thanks. I think that this work is almost done with the latest patch. 
I'll commit tonight after some tests.
The only difference between this patch and TAJO-921 is the absence of square root. Why should we maintan mostly duplicated codes separately?
No offense. Sorry for late review.

Thank you for the review, @jihoonson !
I'll reflect your comments soon.

@jihoonson , I knew that 20 days ago. :) But, there was no way to implement variance at that time, since TAJO-921 is not committed yet. As I mentioned my first comment, we need to change. 

Here, I need your guide how to reduce the redundancy. Is it proper to compute STD_DEV first and square that?
Thank you, @jihoonson .

Hi @navis. Thanks for your contribution. This is a necessary work. 
I looked over the whole patch. In overall, it seems good to me. 
Today I'm off, so it is difficult to leave comments without any computers. I'll finish my review soon.

Thanks for your rapid reply. 
Yes, I also think that will be a good way.
I think we don't need to restrict the maximum number of retrying. How about setting the minimum number?

@jihoonson 

Thank you for your review. I'll check it soon.:)

+1
Though Travis CI build system has an issue when running testcases, but this build issue is far from this patch. Local build on my laptop has passed testcases, and it runs with JDK 6.0.

Great!! @jihoonson 
I will start review. If you fix the findbug warnings in your codes, It would be better
Thank you all guys for your efforts. I also check only some design points.
@navis I think you may very busy to resolve other issues. If you don't mind I will reflect what I commented before committing.

@jihoonson 

The time delay was caused by source sync. After rebasing to the master branch, the build time took as follows.
1. Apply TAJO-1442 patch: 19:13 min
2. Apache Trunk code: 19:58 min

Sure, I'm busy on learning the greatness of SK group till next week.

2015년 4월 13일 월요일, Hyoungjun Kimnotifications@github.com님이 작성한 메시지:

> @navis https://github.com/navis I think you may very busy to resolve
> other issues. If you don't mind I will reflect what I commented before
> committing.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/tajo/pull/501#issuecomment-92215138.

+1 LGTM!
Thanks for your contribution.
I think that it would be great if there are any test cases, but it can be added at https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TAJO-1435.
I'll commit shortly.
@babokim, it seems that the commit log does not include who committed this patch. Please add it from the next commit.
Uploaded one missing commit for this patch, and this is a final version of this task.
@jihoonson Do you mean I should use "--signoff" git option when commit?
I think it doesn't matter how you record it. You can use the `--signoff` option or just write by hand in the log.
I think this patch is very important to make Tajo more stable. So, I'll review it first.

This patch looks good to me. Here is my +1.
The Travis CI failed but it may be caused by TAJO-1526. This issue is trivial and not related any test case. All tests passed on my laptop. So I'll commit soon.
I've rename to RpcClientManager
Performance gain seemed hard to see if it's not running on very big cluster.
@blrunner Could you review this?
I dont think so. If a query involves two or more independent ebs and there are sufficient amount of resources in the cluster, the query is expected to be faster with the concurrent execution of ebs.
Thank you, @babokim !  :)

This patch looks good to me. I had same problem to run TPC-DS query66. After applying this patch that query runs well and all test cases passed.
Here is my +1.
@sirpkt, I misunderstood a contributor worked this patch. I am sorry about that.

Hi @navis 

I failed to build this as follows.

```
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Test set: org.apache.tajo.cli.tsql.TestTajoCli
```

Could you check above error?
seemed needed to be rebased. I'll do that
Okay, thanks. :)
done.
@jinossy you are right. Because clients are calling this APIs with null controller, exception made in server side is not rethrown to client. Seemed need some more works.

Thanks @navis 
I'll review this today. :-)
Thanks @jinossy for addressing missing points.

I updated the patch and it passed 'mvn clean install' in my laptop.

```
Reflecting review comments

- Refactor WindowAggExec code
- Unify window frame start and end bound type
- Remove unnecessary 'static'
- Add parameter test in CurrentValue

NOT CHANGED YET:
- row_number() with DISTINCT still disabled
- LEAD() still AggFunction not WindowAggFunc
```

Hi, @jihoonson . I removed the following redundancy. Now, VarSamp and VarPop use StdDevContext.
- ProtocolBuffer message for VarSamp/VarPop
- Var.java file
I'll finish my review soon.
rebased.

It's ok, @babokim.
Thank you for the review!
I'll commit the patch soon.
I just committed the patch.
Thanks @jinossy and @hyunsik. I've fixed some findbugs warnings related to my patches.

I've enable idle timeout. If all requests is done and client is idle state, client will be closed

```
public static final int RPC_IDLE_TIMEOUT = 43200; // 12 hour
```

+1
thanks for the nice patch!
I think that we can make our rpc cleaner with this patch.

Hi @navis 

This looks good overall to me and I leaved some comments. 
In addition, if possible, could rebase this again? I failed to merge as follows.

```
Removing tajo-rpc/tajo-rpc-protobuf/src/main/java/org/apache/tajo/rpc/RpcConnectionPool.java
Auto-merging tajo-core/src/main/java/org/apache/tajo/master/QueryInProgress.java
Auto-merging tajo-client/src/main/java/org/apache/tajo/client/SessionConnection.java
CONFLICT (content): Merge conflict in tajo-client/src/main/java/org/apache/tajo/client/SessionConnection.java
Auto-merging tajo-client/src/main/java/org/apache/tajo/client/QueryClientImpl.java
Automatic merge failed; fix conflicts and then commit the result.
```

+1
It seems that there are some problems in my machine. Thanks!

Hi @navis. I've reviewed this patch carefully.
Sorry to say, but I think that this is not appropriate for our architecture.
When a client calls `pollQueryStatus()`, the process who waits for the query state to be changed is `TajoMaster`'s rpc server. As you know, we will support multi-tenancy soon. In multi-tenant environment, master's rpc server will be getting slower as more clients submit queries and wait for their results. IMHO, polling in only client will be better than blocking master.
What do you think?

Thanks @jihoonson 

I'll commit this soon. :)

Hi @charsyam 

Could you explain this PR in detail? I don't quite understand this.

I leaved some trivial comments. The patch looks good to me. It's a great job.

Here is my additional comments. You try to change the signature EvalNode::bind to take EvalContext instance in order to get an instance of a launched script engine.

Even though this refactoring is already a breaking change. EvalNode still needs more information about task. In this chance, it would be great if we refactor EvalNode to take more meta context including TajoConf, task attempt information, and shared resources of workers. Then, we can probably remove OverridableConf parameter from all constructors of EvalNode.

If you are concerned with a large patch, we can do this work in another jira. But, it will cause the second breaking change. It is also not good as much as a large patch. You can choose either two breaking changes or a large patch. It's up to you.
Rebased

It looks good overall to me, however it seems to contain the code for ntile function also.
Would you clean up the patch to include code related to nth_value only, @seungunchoe?

@navis 
I will fix network hangs by TAJO-1563

Thanks @hyunsik. I've changed the function name and removed `QueryContextUtil` according to your comment. 

Regarding on refactoring bind() function, I think that it would be better to work in another jira. For this issue, we first should decide what information are required to be passed to EvalNode. I booked another jira (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TAJO-1566).
+1 LGTM!
I got your point and your plan. Please keep going. Here is my +1.

Thanks @sirpkt. In overall, the updated patch looks good to me.
I'm still reviewing this patch. I'll finish soon.
+1 thanks for your work.

I've tested on my laptop. 
@jinossy, do you have any other opinions?

No, Looks good to me. Here is my +1
Thank you for your work

Hi, @blrunner 
CHAR type can have length. :)
But if we make CHAR Column using this command

in tajo-storage/tajo-storage-hdfs/src/test/java/org/apache/tajo/storage/parquet/TestReadWrite.java

``` java
columns.add(new Column("mychar", Type.CHAR)); 
```

but it's length is 0, because it is just using CatalogUtil.newSimpleDataType

and Scheme class already use condition code in addColumn method.
But I think it can cause some mistakes easily.

So I think it is better to move this condition code into CatalogUtil.newSimpleDataType
What do you think?
Even though it is trivial change, it seems to be a critical issue. Other changes look good to me. I left one comment.
+1 Ship it
Thank you for the review.

branch-0.10.1 is required TAJO-1497
I will create new jira task

Could you update other files in proto directory ?

```
tajo-rpc/tajo-rpc-protobuf/src/main/proto
```
Oh, sure! Thank you, @jinossy
@sirpkt thanks for your nice work. Since this is a new feature which will be very useful and popularly used, I've carefully reviewed. Please think about my comments. Thanks.
Hi, @jinossy . I finished updating according to your advice. Thank you!
+1. I just a minor comment. Please address before commit.

There still remains legacy licenses as follows. Would you mind updating together?

```
$ find . -name "*.proto" -exec grep -H -n -i "korea" {} \;
./tajo-rpc/tajo-rpc-protobuf/src/main/proto/DummyProtos.proto:2: * Copyright 2012 Database Lab., Korea Univ.
./tajo-rpc/tajo-rpc-protobuf/src/main/proto/RpcProtos.proto:2: * Copyright 2012 Database Lab., Korea Univ.
./tajo-rpc/tajo-rpc-protobuf/src/main/proto/TestProtocol.proto:2: * Copyright 2012 Database Lab., Korea Univ.
./tajo-rpc/tajo-rpc-protobuf/src/main/proto/TestProtos.proto:2: * Copyright 2012 Database Lab., Korea Univ.
```
@jihoonson I changed TIMEZONE's type to DEFAULT :)

Hi, @jihoonson . I think you are saying the same files mentioned by @jinossy . 
Those files are changed together in a second commit ( https://github.com/dongjoon-hyun/tajo/commit/41bee81a69da939e74fc45efaf708c4e59d67013 ) in this pull request. If you don't mind, could you check the second commit again?

Thank you for your review.
I will commit it soon after I upload patch for branch-0.10.1 in jira

Thanks @charsyam. We had a discussion about the session variable system in Tajo, and finally found that the variable type of `TIMEZONE` should be `DEFAULT` rather than `CLI_SIDE_VAR`. 
This patch looks good to me, but I think that it would be great if we have a test code for this change.
Would you mind adding a test?

This change is trivial, but will reduce many mistakes.
Would you trigger Travis or Jenkins again after rebasing?
@dongjoon-hyun OK, I will test this patch using TPC-DC queries.

We need to have some discussion on this feature. In this case, as @dongjoon-hyun said, the column in the order-by clause can be identified as the column in the select clause. However, IMO, we need have a general rule to handle this issue. Do you guys have any knowledge about the well-know rules?
Hi, @jihoonson . I'm not sure about that point. If you give me some advice, I will revise this patch in more general form later. What about asking @hyunsik , too?
I think that is the first thing what contributors should do when they take an issue. I'll investigate too.

Hi @charsyam and @blrunner, thanks for your work. 
As @charsyam said, `CHAR` type can have a variable length. The code in `Schema::add()` seems to give a default length for this type. I agree on that this patch will reduce mistakes because many other codes use `CatalogUtil.newSimpleDataType()` directly.
@jihoonson I rebased it. and it passed :)
+1 thanks!

@jihoonson , up to my knowledge, sorting is based on the result of selection by the SQL definition. In other words, sorting stage is processed after producing the table. So, I added `normalizeSort` function that look the schema part up first and handle the other cases in pre-defined `normalize`. I thought it is general. Could you elaborate what you mean? I'm not sure what you mean by `general rule`.

Hi, @jihoonson . I found a related description in PostgresSQL documentation.

http://www.postgresql.org/docs/9.4/static/queries-order.html

  _After a query has produced an output table (after the select list has been processed) it can optionally be sorted_. If sorting is not chosen, the rows will be returned in an unspecified order. The actual order in that case will depend on the scan and join plan types and the order on disk, but it must not be relied on. A particular output ordering can only be guaranteed if the sort step is explicitly chosen.

BufferPool allocator is to be UnpooledByteBufAllocator when a tajo.test.enabled is set to enable. 
IMO, we don’t need pooling for testing.
Thank you for fast reviewing, @jinossy !

Sorry for confusing you. I mean, this issue is related to SQL name resolution rules rather than sort execution. 

Basically, when there are two or more columns that have the same name in a SQL, qualifiers must be explicitly specified for those columns. Tajo also follows this rule so far. And now, you are trying to add a new rule. 
The general rule means that the new rule should be sufficiently general to handle most cases with a few unavoidable exceptions. So, we need to discuss to design the new rule. Without discussion, people like me can have many questions about the rule. For example, your patch allows to omit the qualifier of a column in the order-by clause if the select clause involves a column of the same name. So, some of my questions are, why this rule focuses on only order-by clause? why does the same rule can be applied to group-by clauses or any other clauses? what happens if the select and order-by clauses involve two or more columns?
I've also checked pgsql. It seems to use this rule for only the order-by clause. I think that we need the exact reason to make a solid rule. 
The above quote looks to describe the order-by clause, and not much helpful to investigate this issue.

Oh. Thank you, @jihoonson .Now, I understand more about your concern and what causes disagreement.

First, this issue is related ORDER BY SQL name resolution rules rather than SQL name resolution. The scope is totally different. I think we need to focus what is the meaning of ORDER BY clause. In that sense, please note that _"it can optionally be sorted"_. ORDER BY is defined on the SELECT clause. If you ask 'Why this rule focuses on only order-by clause?', the reason is ORDER BY clause is different from the others. 

Second, let me answer your remaining concerns. 
- Why does the same rule can be applied to group-by clauses or any other clauses? --> We can not. As you know, the other clause affect SELECT clause; e.g. GROUP BY clause will generate aggregate functions on SELECT clause. 
- What happens if the select and order-by clauses involve two or more columns? --> Each column among them should be needed to be resolved independently. In case of multiple matching, we should print out 'Ambiguous Column Name Error' again. I think it is logical. If you agree with this, I will add more codes and testcases for this.

Thank you for your kind guide, again, @jihoonson .
I've never heard "ORDER BY SQL name resolution rules". Is it SQL standard?
What I mean is 'a name resolution rule for SQL order-by clause'. It's a narrow-scoped part of your SQL name resolution rule. I doesn't mean another rule.
